coauthors.bio: Aharon Varady, founding director of the Open Siddur Project, is a copyright researcher and amateur book scanner. He prepares digital images and new digital editions of prayer books and related works in the Public Domain in order to make their constituent parts (prayers, translations, annotations, etc.) publicly accessible for collaborative transcription by project volunteers. coauthors.name: Maurice Liber
coauthors.bio: Rabbi Maurice Liber (1884‚Äì1956), born in Warsaw, he was a scholar and the chief rabbi of France. Liber came to Paris with his parents at the age of four. After graduating from the Ecole Rabbinique de Paris in 1907 he began lecturing on Jewish history there. In 1911 he was appointed assistant to the chief rabbi of Paris, serving as an army chaplain and receiving the Croix de Guerre during World War ‚Ö†. In 1920 Liber became rabbi at the Rue de la Victoire synagogue, in 1921 lecturer in the history of rabbinic Judaism at the Ecole Pratique des Hautes Etudes, and in 1927 succeeded his teacher Isra√´l L√©vi as professor. He was appointed director of religious education by the Paris Consistoire in 1930 and, two years later, head of the Ecole Rabbinique. In 1934 Liber was appointed chief rabbi of France par interim, to assist the aging Isra√´l L√©vi in his task. Under the German occupation of France during World War ‚Ö°, he strove hard to safeguard the Ecole Rabbinique ‚Äì which had been evacuated to unoccupied southern France ‚Äì and the religious character of the Consistoire. He also strove to maintain some sort of Jewish education, both legal and underground. Liber's chief field of research was French-Jewish history. He is best known by his biography of Rashi (1905; Eng. tr. 1906). He wrote a series of articles, based on archival sources, under the title "Les Juifs et la convocation des Etats G√©n√©raux" (in REJ, vols. 63‚Äì66, 1912‚Äì13), and another series, "Napol√©on et les Juifs" (ibid., vols. 71‚Äì72, 1920‚Äì21). On liturgy he wrote, among other works, La R√©citation du Schema‚Ä¶ (1909), "La Formation de la liturgie Synagogale" (in Annuaire de l'Ecole des Hautes Etudes, 1933/34), and "Structure and History of the Tefilah" (in JQR, 40 (1949/50), 331‚Äì57). Liber also wrote an extensive introduction to the reprint of M. Schwab's French translation of the Palestinian Talmud (1932). Liber opposed Zionism, calling it a national theory unacceptable to those who believe that emancipation resolved the national question for the Jews. Though deeply religious, he felt compelled to compromise with the facts of French synagogue life, such as the use of an organ.

Lambert contributed a number of articles to periodicals like the Revue des Etudes Juives and the Journal Asiatique. He also contributed to the publication of the Corpus Inscriptionum Semiticarum and was involved with a French translation of the Bible that was issued by the French rabbinate. coauthors.name: Consistoire central isra√©lite de France
coauthors.bio: The Consistoire central isra√©lite de France (English: Israelite Central Consistory of France) is an institution originally created by Napoleon I by the Imperial Decree of 17 March 1808 to administer Jewish worship and congregations in France. Given Napoleon's political emancipation of the Jews, he wanted a representative body that could deal with his government. He also directed the establishment of regional Israelite Consistories, subordinate to the Central Consistory, across France and Italy. The consistories were ranked as √©tablissements publics du culte (public-law corporations of worship). In its first year, the consistory was led by Rabbi David Sinzheim, who headed the Assembly of Notables and the Grand Sanhedrin that preceded it in organization.

content:
La Tefila du Soldat is an abridged bilingual Hebrew-French prayerbook for French-Jewish soldiers prepared in 1939 by Rabbi Maurice Liber, the former interim Chief Rabbi of France under Rabbi Isra√´l L√©vi (from 1934-1939). In addition to abridged liturgy, the prayerbook also contains a curated selection of te·∏•inot in vernacular French, and psalms in French translation. Rabbi Isaie Schwartz, appointed chief rabbi in 1939, wrote the introductory letter to Jewish soldiers at the start of the French section of the siddur. In it, he notes the prayerbook is, essential, a copy of one offered to French-Jewish soldiers by the Consistoire central israel√≠te de France during World War ‚Ö†.

The note to the first edition explains that the contents are mostly derived from material found in Pri√®res D‚Äôun C≈ìur Isra√©lite (1848/1853) by the former chief Rabbi Arnaud Aron and the Guide du croyant isra√©lite (1857) by the former chief Rabbi L. Wogue. The note also names the scholar, Dr. Mayer Lambert, as having (posthumously) contributed to the siddur.

In the printed edition, the Hebrew and French sections open from the right and from the left, respectively. In this digital edition, the French pages follow the Hebrew pages. An index at the end of the prayerbook provides corresponding page numbers for Hebrew prayers in French translation.

For more information on Jewish military participation in the French Army in World War II, find this 2017 post at the They Were Soldiers blog.

 

This work was scanned by Aharon Varady for the Open Siddur Project from a volume held in the collection of the HUC Klau Library, Cincinnati, Ohio. (Thank you!) This work is cross-posted to the Internet Archive.
